div.p: I received in due season your letter of Jan 27 bringing me the agreeable intelligence that the sick ones of the family had nearly recovered, and the news that my new brother was to be called Alexander William, these I think are very good names, since they are not common to many members of the family.

In case you should not have received my letter in answer to yours of the 17 & 18, I state that I received those in due season, and at the same time the letter and draft of Baring Brothers & cr. Tell sister Mary and brother Johnny that I received their kind letters and will soon answer them.
I am very sorry that Johnny's application has been put off so by the government, but hope that Commodore Parker's influence will decide the case in his favour.

You will have seen by the papers the particulars of the situation of Paris on the 29' Jany; since that day it appears certain that the extensive precautions taken by the government were fully justified by the information it had received of the intentions of a certain portion of the community. The assembly here has not yet passed the organic laws on acted upon the affair of the Clubs. I was present during part of the sitting of Saturday, the day which I understood had been set apart for the discussion of the proposition Rateau

The assembly usually meets at about 1 1/2 and adjourns at about 6 o' clock. I was present in the chamber from 1 to 5. At about 1 1/2 o' clock, 1/4 of the members I judge being present, the assembly was called to order by general Lamonicierevici Prest in came

to order at about 1 hour after, and remained at order for short intervals during the time that I remained; the rest of the time there was nothing but confusion and uproar in spite of the endeavours of the President and officers to keep order. I heard speeches from Messieurs Rousseau Dupere Perree & Leon Faucher the minister of the Interior. The letter did not show as much eloquence as I expected from a man in his position. Cavaignae is quite a plain looking man, Lamartine very fine looking; Thiers is a small man, appears to be about 60, and is very good looking - these the ministers and Berrier the lawyer, were the important characters that I saw. The President of the Republic having some time ago asked Mr Rush to present to him the officiers of our service who were in Paris, we attended his soiree and were presented to him on last Thursday evening. I had a short conversation with him, and was very much pleased with the manner in which he received us. He is a very small man, but very good looking; he appears very care worn. Mr Bancroft was present at this

soiree, and is still in Paris. Cavaignae, Lamartine, Arago & c never attend the soirees of the President. Give my love to Ma and all the family, and a kiss to Martha and the baby, and remember me kindly to Mr Fay and family.
